body: @zhztheplayer Thanks for reviewing! Could you take one final look at the last change before this is merged?
ping @julianhyde
Also pls address Julian's comments in JIRA(eg BINARY vs VARCHAR)

Sorry @julianhyde I just saw the email notification from JIRA, and replied within the ticket. Following the conversation here, I will push a new commit against master (there's no point of keeping the current commit)

> > Reviewing now. Please see comments in the JIRA case.
> 
> Thanks for reviewing. The build is passing. We can merge this along with your revision or I can cherry-pick your commit and update this PR

@julianhyde , I have cherry-picked your revision and updated this PR. I think we can merge this once the build finishes.
@michaelmior thanks for the reminder. I just rebased and updated the change. I think the discussion has pretty much finalized. Can you take another look if possible?

> Also pls address Julian's comments in JIRA(eg BINARY vs VARCHAR)

Ok, I'll address it ,Thanks.
LGTM
It would help if you could also resolve the current merge conflicts.
@pengzhiwei2018 Could you resolve the conflicts?

> @pengzhiwei2018 Could you resolve the conflicts?

Thanks for start this review! Done for it!

> Also pls address Julian's comments in JIRA(eg BINARY vs VARCHAR)

I have addressed some comments. But as for "TO_BASE64 takes a BINARY or VARBINARY, not a VARCHAR, as argument." , considering Mysql specifies that "Converts the string argument to base-64 encoded form and returns the result as a character string with the connection character set and collation. " https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/string-functions.html#function_to-base64.  I'm not sure if it must change its argument to BINARY or VARBINARY?  So I let TO_BASE64 can take both string and  binary string as argument.  Hope get some advises. Thanks.
@chunweilei @julianhyde  Thank you very much, Comments addressed.
hi @zhztheplayer Thank you very much, Comments addressed.
@danny0405, thank you for your review. I believe I found something similar to what you requested in your comment. Please have a look again.
I made a comment in the JIRA.

@MGelbana Sorry i'm too busy to review your PR, i will try if i have time in following days.
Commit message should almost never contain "fix". "RelDecorrelator throws when decorrelating an aggregate function with more than one argument"
@chunweilei @hsyuan  Can you please review this for PR for me ?
Looks like the same change was done in https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/1254. @danny0405, is it possible to collaborate with that PR, since it was opened earlier?

> Looks like the same change was done in #1254. @danny0405, is it possible to collaborate with that PR, since it was opened earlier?

I worked this PR based on #1254, and if we make sure this fix is ok, i would close this PR and rebase the logic in #1254 the merge it in.
Please see my comments in the other PR.
Is it able to have test cases for the changes? Also, please correct the case of word "support" to "Support" in commit message, as well as JIRA/PR title.

> Please see my comments in the other PR.

Thanks, @julianhyde ,i would like to close this one.

@MGelbana Just a note that commit messages should describe what was done and do not necessarily have to match the tile of the JIRA. Something like "Support parsing PostgreSQL TEXT type in Babel parser" would be more appropriate.
@vlsi Could you take another look?

@michaelmior , the review comments are resolved.

However it looks like the change fails the build, and I have not analyzed the reason.
Thanks!
@ijokarumawak What JDK version are you using? It passes on CI with JDK 10.

@michaelmior , it does not.
I think the reason one of Travis job passes is it runs with `SLOW_TESTS=Y`, so only a subset of tests is executed.
@asereda-gs @julianhyde  Hello， I have made some modification, welcome comment. Thanks.

Regarding `isSemiOrAntiJoin` and `projectsRight`. I saw one or places in the code where I thought it would be more natural to write
```
switch (join.getJoinType) {
case SEMI:
case ANTI:
  ...
```
than to write
```
if (join.projectsRight()) {
  ...
```

I encourage people to use a `switch` on join types if is easier to comprehend.
@zhztheplayer I have add the test case, can you help me review it again?
@XuMingmin I will check this PR over the week-end
@wenhuitang I will check over week-end
@zhztheplayer Do you mind having a final look?
@XuMingmin I understand what you're saying, but I'm not sure is a good idea. Just add a special reserved keyword(`KAFKA_TIMESTAMP`) in KafkaAdapter maybe too  weird, but it will make it easy to use.

Thanks @walterddr and @michaelmior, I think it's good to go.

A minor suggestion - as parser might go into conflict when parsing member functions or regular functions after applying the PR, we'd better to push CALCITE-2906 forward earlier, say, we can mark that one as 1.21.0, so that we don't forget to come up with a final solution.

@XuMingmin - Thanks for the comments. Just out of curiosity (If I get your point correctly), how does the column`KAFKA_TIMESTAMP` distinguish with the existing `MSG_TIMESTAMP`? Does that mean we should emit 2 different timestamp columns?
Let's continue the discussion in JIRA - https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-3073 (since it becomes a design discussion).
Build is passing. @zabetak , @laurentgo , please take a look when you have some time.
Obviously this is not a bug. I closed the Jira issue and will consider opening a new one to fix the returned column type name.
Good work @wenhuitang, just a few minor things that may be worth considering!
There's a typo in `includePosixOpertaors` that should be corrected.

Thanks for handling this @michaelmior !
@zabetak @danny0405 @julianhyde Regarding the open discussion about deprecating Linq4j CorrelateJoinType in favor of the new (more general) enum JoinType: if nobody opposes, I propose to create a separate jira ticket and prepare a PR ASAP so that we can mark it as deprecated in 1.20 (and eventually remove it in a subsequent version)
These commits don't clearly state the problem that is being fixed.
@zabetak I think your comments have been addressed. FYI I plan to merge @siddharthteotia change today.

@zhztheplayer I already have an experiment on CALCITE-2906 and seems like the concern is less obvious after I rebased with latest master. but you are right the risk is there. I will also closely involve with CALCITE-2906 and agree it should be fix soon.
I will find time to take a look.
I will have a look right now, thanks for the reminder!
Thank you for your time. Done.

@danny0405, I believe you're suggesting to reuse `org.apache.calcite.sql.fun.SqlCastFunction` instead of creating a new one `org.apache.calcite.sql.fun.PostgreSQLCastOperator`. The difficulties I faced are:

- Unparsing the operator will produce the `CAST` syntax, not the original one `::`, which is ok I guess, what do you think ? May be not ok ?
- The modification I made enabled me to parse the operator but I can't return a function (i.e. `CAST`) at this point because the production is returning `List<Object>`. I will try again and see if I can do this differently.

Thanks.
Hi @julianhyde, I have update all the detailed explanation (the bug, the test case that trigger the bug and why) in the description of JIRA CALCITE-3118. Can you take another look please?
The CI is broken.
@MGelbana You can customize the cast operator unparse logic, see https://github.com/apache/calcite/commit/4e1b68e3c0b2a90832cc790c6166cebb14ae2970 for a reference

@hsyuan Comments addressed, thanks for review.
But it is confusing why SqlOperatorBaseTest.testSimilarToOperator failed?
some fix-up in https://github.com/chunweilei/calcite/commit/77365bb137742c41c791785a251f00f47b8760bc.

Can someone make a pass to fix code style? E.g. adding a field with two blank lines before, no blank lines after. And indentation.

And move it to the "dialect-specific operators" in the doc.
Do we need so many overloads in SqlFunctions? I suspect that `chr(long)` would be sufficient.
It is because JDK 13, see the fix: https://github.com/apache/calcite/commit/2b91eb2ee5cbc1e9a6323f98e9628385faf42e1b
Can you rebase on latest master? It will trigger the test again once you pushed.

> Can someone make a pass to fix code style? E.g. adding a field with two blank lines before, no blank lines after. And indentation. And move it to the "dialect-specific operators" in the doc.

I made some fix-up in https://github.com/chunweilei/calcite/commit/77365bb137742c41c791785a251f00f47b8760bc.

> Do we need so many overloads in SqlFunctions? I suspect that chr(long) would be sufficient.

Makes sense.

Can you improve the description?
hi @julianhyde @hsyuan Thank you very much，Comments addressed.I have modified this PR.

Any suggestions on fixing this error. I dont have a Window machine, so could not reproduce it locally.
> 2019-06-12 01:58:46,142 [pool-1-thread-1] ERROR - Failed to locate the winutils binary in the hadoop binary path
java.io.IOException: Could not locate executable null\bin\winutils.exe in the Hadoop binaries.
	at org.apache.hadoop.util.Shell.getQualifiedBinPath(Shell.java:382)
	at org.apache.hadoop.util.Shell.getWinUtilsPat

Thanks for your feedback.
@julianhyde @zabetak , I have addressed your comments in the PR.
If you don't like what the `druidChecker` method does, why not create a variant of it? Either with a parameter, or a new method. It's an opportunity to write a clear comment.
Overall LGTM. Please address small comments (in docs) and squash commits into one.

> Overall LGTM. Please address small comments (in docs) and squash commits into one.

Hi @asereda-gs ，I have already addressed. Thanks a lot for your time on this PR.

> Good work @wenhuitang, just a few minor things that may be worth considering!

Hello, @zabetak  , thanks for your reviews. I have addressed  the test case. As for the JdbcConvention#toString(),  it returns the name of the Convention which is "JDBC." + name. And the name is specified when creating a JdbcSchema.   So it  maybe not obey the description pattern of the rule. As far as I know, the description of JdbcToEnumerableConverterRule is "JdbcToEnumerableConverterRule:" + out too. To solve this problem, I add a unique signature which obey the description pattern of the rule in JdbcConvention and override JdbcConvention#toString to get this signature.

> Rather then `(temp.length() / 76) > 0` why not write `temp.length() > 76`?
> 
> Punctuation consistent with surrounding code. Rather than `/** SQL TO_BASE64(string) function*/` write `/** SQL TO_BASE64(string) function. */`
> 
> Rather than `assertEquals(expected, actual)` use `assertThat(actual, is(expected))`. Easier to read.
> 
> Your algorithm creates a temp string and chews it down shorter and shorter. That is an O n^2 algorithm. Instead create one string, an offset into it (`for (int i = 0; i + 76 < s.length(); i += 76)`) and use `StringBuilder.append(s, i, i + 76)` or similar.

Hello, @julianhyde Thanks for your time on this PR, I have addressed the comments,  do you have time to have a look at the PR again?

@wenhuitang thanks for addressing Julians comments.
I left one more. Pls take a look
hi @julianhyde @hsyuan Can you continue to take up your valuable time to review this pr?
I am not sure, but should NEW have only 1 argument?
Hi, @asereda-gs @vlsi, thanks a lot, I have already addressed the new comments.

>I think the exists tests should already cover the code, so missing test is ok for me.

Nothing prevents from re-introducing the bug.
hi @chunweilei  Thank you very much, Comments addressed.

If I understand correctly the NEW operator is some kind of prefix operator to be used before call to user defined constructor functions. I'm not sure that just passing list of expressions to NEW is a correct usage.

Thanks for the update @wenhuitang . I've seen what you are trying to do by overriding `JdbcConvention.toString()` but I am afraid it might backfire on us: 

- The debug logs of the planner and possibly other places will be more difficult to read.
-All JdbcRules are going to be registered to the planner even if they come from the same convention (instantiated multiple times).

I have to think a bit if there is another alternative and if it is really worth it getting into the process of normalizing the convention name. Give me a few days to think on it.
hi @hsyuan @ihuzenko Thank you very much,I will take the time to continue tracking.

Not nothing. Human diligence prevents it.

Even if there is a regression test someone could remove it. But we assume good faith, so we assume that doesn't happen.
@julianhyde a gentle ping here, can you please take a close look? @danny0405 has agreed that this is a bug in the jira.
The way to reproduce the issue is to create as many different RelDataType as you can and canonize it, until it runs out of memory.
Hey @LiShuMing, it seems that you have checkstyle violations. In most cases before submitting a PR it is highly recommended to test that the build passes locally `mvn clean install`.
LGTM

> Hey @LiShuMing, it seems that you have checkstyle violations. In most cases before submitting a PR it is highly recommended to test that the build passes locally `mvn clean install`.

Sorry, it's my first merge request. I'll fix it right now.

@vlsi / @julianhyde I'm fine with this review. 
Do you have any concerns if I merge it ?

The first word of a commit message should rarely be “fix”.

@wenhuitang According to calcite's convention, the title should just describe the problem.
